data.title: [Feature Request] Add support for making package recommendations
data.body:
### Problem

A package that has additional _plugin_ packages that perhaps enable a tight integration with other packages or environments currently has no method outside of documentation to recommend their installation.

 - `minimap-linter` when both `linter` and `minimap` are installed
 - `build-coffee` when `build` is installed and the user opens a CoffeeScript file

A package that simply offers additional functionality when another package is installed has no avenue to recommend outside of documentation or [atom-package-deps](https://www.npmjs.com/package/atom-package-deps).

 - `hyperclick` when `go-plus` or `flow-ide` are installed. If I install a `hyperclick-javascript` package I assume it would use `atom-package-deps` to install `hyperclick` as it would be useless otherwise. Both `go-plus` and `flow-idea` have a fair amount of functionality outside of simply being a `hyperclick` provider.

Atom currently has dozens of builtin `language-` packages. What if instead these language packages were not builtin but _recommended_ to the user when the user opened the file for the first time? 

### Proposed Solution

A new package, `recommendations`, would be accepted in Atom core. This package would define the UI and the consume the `atom.recommendations` service that any package could provide to make recommendations. Alternatively this could be put into the `settings-view` package as recommended packages might make sense to be displayed above or below featured packages in the install area.

Atom core itself would make no recommendations for community packages.

Recommended packages would remember what packages recommended them and the UI would communicate this so that users would not feel that Atom itself is recommending them. Below is a mock that could exist on the Install tab of settings-view.

![screen shot 2017-07-11 at 2 31 22 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/753919/28091859-414c123e-6646-11e7-91a0-48e20ceb8146.png)

When a new recommendation is made it could show in the bottom-right similar to when updates are available. A message should also be presented to the user. Here is how this process looks in VS Code:

![screen shot 2017-07-11 at 2 42 27 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/753919/28092128-2fec5cdc-6647-11e7-8a3a-77539c92684b.png)

`go-plus` does do something like this already (see below) but we could formalize what it does and make the UX much cleaner by integrating the recommendation process into core.

![screen shot 2017-07-11 at 2 45 09 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/753919/28092336-cc0b2f08-6647-11e7-89d4-c2d19bafc6be.png)

Below is a quick mock of what it could look like unified. I'd still want the package desc. as well as perhaps a select/unselect and Install Selected/All button.

![screen shot 2017-07-11 at 2 49 18 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/753919/28092420-2b1107ac-6648-11e7-9555-3282c783f4ce.png)

data.title: Tree View crashes Atom when opening file on remounted disk volume
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages


### Description

The editor crashes when using "tree view" to open a file in a "project folder" that is located on a **re**mounted drive.

Please note that it is not necessary to actually access the volume (by e.g. opening a file). It seems that the volume disappearing/reappearing is enough for the editor to crash.

Also note that this behavior is **not** present when using File -> Open on the volume. Hence I believe it is related to the "tree view".

Crash logs from _Scenario 2_ has been attached.


[e0003a1c-b264-414b-849c-96d6ce864538.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1138162/e0003a1c-b264-414b-849c-96d6ce864538.txt)
[operation_log.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1138163/operation_log.txt)
[e0003a1c-b264-414b-849c-96d6ce864538.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/1138171/e0003a1c-b264-414b-849c-96d6ce864538.zip)


### Steps to Reproduce

Note that this crash is reproducible in both _safe_ and _regular_ mode.

#### Scenario 1:

1. Make sure the volume is **not** already a "project folder" in Atom.
2. Mount the volume in DiskCryptor.
3. Start Atom.
3. Add a "project folder" pointing to the mounted volume.
4. Unmount the volume in DiskCryptor.
5. Remount the volume in DiskCryptor.
6. Open any file from the mounted volume.

#### Scenario 2:

1. Make sure the volume **is** already a "project folder" in Atom.
2. Mount the volume in DiskCryptor.
3. Start Atom.
4. Unmount the volume in DiskCryptor.
5. Remount the volume in DiskCryptor.
6. Open any file from the mounted volume.

#### Scenario 3:

This is my daily usage scenario.
The volume has been automatically unmounted the the end of the day.
At the beginning of each work day, I wake the computer from sleep mode.

1. Make sure the volume **is** already a "project folder" in Atom.
2. Mount the volume in DiskCryptor.
3. Start Atom.
4. Unmount the volume in DiskCryptor.
5. Put the computer to sleep (and go home for the day).
6. Wake up the computer.
7. Remount the volume in DiskCryptor.
8. Open any file from the mounted volume.

#### Expected behavior:

The editor should not crash when opening a file on a volume that was first mounted, then unmounted and finally remounted.

#### Actual behavior:

The editor crashes when trying to open any file on a **re**mounted volume.
This is regardless of whether any file (on any volume) was opened or not.

#### Reproduces how often:

Every time the scenario is repeated.


### Versions

`atom --version`
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

This is the current version I'm using, but this problem has been present much, much longer than this. Perhaps for years? I'm not certain.

`apm --version`
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 ia32
python 3.6.1
git 2.10.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015

Windows 10 Enterprise


### Additional Information

This happens on Windows 10 using [DiskCryptor](https://diskcryptor.net/wiki/Main_Page) to simulate an unplugged volume. Presumably, it is related to a volume being remounted, but it **could** also be related to network shares, as described in [ticket 14760](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14760).

**Prerequisite**
Use e.g. DiskCryptor to create a new volume.
Place a text file in that volume (in order to have content that can be opened by Atom).

data.title: Fix regressions handling mousedown on Linux and macOS
data.body:
Fixes #8648

This PR fixes two regressions related to mouse handling introduced in the latest editor rewrite (#13880) and the upgrade to Electron 1.6.x (#12696).

* On Linux, the middle mouse button pasting text twice (#8648). This regressed because Chrome now seems to synthesize textInput events on mouseup when clicking with the middle button. We had custom logic to emulate this behavior that was rendered redundant by this change.

* On Mac, ctrl-clicking is interpreted by the OS as a right click that brings up the context menu. We weren't bailing out in this case, which caused the cursor to move after the context menu had closed.

We should hot-fix this to 1.19-releases once it is merged.

/cc @ungb

data.title: Atom doesn't reflect changes in environment for subsequent invocations of `atom .`
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I'm running Atom on Windows (with command prompt), so I'm not sure if the issue is reproducible on other platforms. All invocations of `atom .` seem to reflect the state of the environment from the first time I invoked atom. Moreover, when using WSL (Bash on Windows), atom seems to completely ignore any environment variables I've set in the shell beforehand. This might be an unrelated issue, but I've ruled out using WSL as a workaround.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. In one command prompt window, `set FOO=bar`
2. In the same command prompt window, `atom .`
3. In another command prompt window, `set FOO=foo`
4, In this other command prompt window, `atom .`
5. Print `process.env` in the Javascript console for both atom windows.

**Expected behavior:** `FOO` in the first window should be equal to `bar` and `FOO` in the second window should be equal to `foo`.

**Actual behavior:** Both windows report `FOO` as `bar`.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Windows 10 Build 15063.332 x64

### Additional Information

I've noticed related closed issues or merged pull requests, but they seem to focus more on OS X. Whatever the fix was in the past, at the very least it doesn't work on Windows.

data.title: Atom 1.18+ token matching behaving strangely
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I noticed a strange behaviour when it comes to syntax highlighting. At first I thought it's a bug in my language package as I developed it myself for a custom language. But then I noticed that the issue only appears when using atom v1.18.0 and above.

By using the development mode I can see that the problem is, that the limits of the structures I have defined via grammar rules are not recognized as expected. Visually, they seem to be "shifted" but I think the problem is more complex.

Here's what some part of a script in this language look like in v1.17.2:

![atom1 17 2-no_error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/729045/28021719-275564ce-6589-11e7-830b-767c35c06e39.png)

And here's what the same part of the script look like in v1.18.0 (and above, I also tried 1.19.0-beta3):

![atomv1 18 0-error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/729045/28021722-2c9685bc-6589-11e7-880b-57e203f9009e.png)

I think this visual comparison already gives an impression of the problem. I could also provide the relevant snippet of the grammar and a structural comparison of what parts are exactly recognized by atom here, if this would also help.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install [my language package](https://atom.io/packages/language-oxpath) in atom version less than v1.18
2. Install my language package in atom version v1.18 or above
3. Create a file with extension .oxp or .oxt with content like this:
  ```
   :<test=string(.)>
   :<test2>
  ```
  and see the difference in rendering.

**Expected behavior:** The token matching / syntax highlighting should work as it did in previous versions of atom.

**Actual behavior:** The matching of tokens and structures seems to have changed from v1.18.0 on. 
Might also be the case that my grammar has its own issues and that some reasonable change in the way atom handles those grammar rules resulted in revealing those flaws. If this is the case, I would like to know what changed and how I could fix my grammar.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Change resulting in this behaviour seems to have been introduced in 1.18.0 - I have tested on v1.18.0-beta1, -beta2 and -beta3 as well as v1.18.0 (stable) and also 1.19.0-beta3. For comparison I checked v1.17.2 as the most recent version before the issue appeared.
I am running Atom on Linux, Ubuntu 16.04 x64.

### Additional Information
none

data.title: Feature - keymap cross OS
data.body:
I was thinking if it was a good idea to have cross OS keymap for Mac and Windows, and the Common keymap for both.

It would be like this.

- _keymap.cson_ still serve as it is now. it's the common keymap config
- _keymap-mac.cson_ for mac only keymap config, it override the _keymap.cson_
- _keymap-win.cson_ for windows only keymap config, it override the _keymap.cson_

I came up with this when I was using sync-settings.

data.body:

### Prerequisites

* [x ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Brand new install, first time user. Right when I open the program in regular or safe mode, the +Install screen says 'self signed certificate in certificate chain' in the Featured Packages section and when I try to search. Picture included. So I am unable to install packages. I've also tried from the command line using apm install. I've searched multiple threads that have this issue but all of the solutions already match my setup like checking environment variables and so on.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22378341/27980254-4a9b1c88-6342-11e7-81ce-5f9494919c5e.png)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open program
2. Go to +Install page

**Expected behavior:** Search and install packages

**Actual behavior:** Error

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

On Atom 1.19.0-beta2, the editor is consistently crashing within ~30 seconds of opening any file. This started suddenly, and I don't *believe* I changed anything. 

The problem continues in safe mode, with a nuked configuration, with window state cleared, and for various file types in various folders.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file in the editor
2. Click to place the cursor in the file
3. Wait ~15-30 seconds.

**Expected behavior:** Nothing. The editor remains responsive.

**Actual behavior:** The editor becomes unresponsive until I receive a "the editor has crashed" message and am prompted to open this issue.

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

This is not a bug report but a feature request.  When creating packages, you can put cson files under the `snippets` folder but only the top-level folder is scanned.  I would like to propose a recursive lookup under the `snippets` folders in order to better organize snippets in a tree like hierarchy.

I know you allow fo rmultiple snippets per file, but when you have a large collection of snippets, it is easier to organize via folders first.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a hierarchy under `snippets` folder in a package.

```
+ snippets
  + wirebox
      + snippets.cson
  + testbox 
     + skeletons
        + files.cson
```
2. Reload the workbench to activate snippets


**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

For the snippets to register

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

None of the nested snippets are registered

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions

Mac OS Latest
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.0

data.title: Feature: Titlebar like Github Desktop (Windows)
data.body:
## Atom
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21206831/27933793-251d231a-62a3-11e7-9d2d-3a8542da53fa.png)


## Github Desktop (Beta)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21206831/27934049-3bec3044-62a4-11e7-9a4b-27a3ae9a9902.png)


## Description
The new Desktop Client for Github has a really sexy Titlebar. 
Not only because it matches the color of the application but also because it doesn't use the OS default application menu but a custom one inside the Titlebar. 
Unfortunately, the windows default Titlebar and the application menu are very ugly. Especially the application menu looks like Windows 95 when Microsoft introduced this grayish style which they didn't changed since for it. Sure, it's sad that developers have to come up with custom solutions but the windows version would look soo much better with a custom title bar like the Github Client.

A custom Titlebar would also be nice on other platforms but on macOS, the application menu isn't in the window but in the menubar wich looks great and it should be there. On most Linux distros the Titlebar and the application menu have at least the same style so it doesn't look so bad there. Therefore the windows version of Atom is worst one and needs this feature the most.

Other Issues:
#13249 
#4599

data.title: Previous automatically-saved project state detected popups every time I'm opening a folder
data.body:
Ive removed default content because it's not like a technical issue.

Because I'm using polymer-ide I have to open each component in different window (can't add another folder to current project). Every time I'm opening a folder I'm seeing this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3320020/27925925-69acc730-627e-11e7-8102-1e27ea4f521e.png)

Is there's a way to avoid this popup? I really don't care at which state it will open.
And this is happening on MacOs only.

data.title: Upgrade text-buffer to v13.0.6
data.body: This changes marker layer `onDidUpdate` events to occur after text-buffer `onDidChangeText` events. Also, those events will now be triggered at the end of the outermost transaction, analogously to `onDidChangeText`.
